questions.text: A 43-year-old farmer presents with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, burning red eyes, fever with chills, calf tenderness, and joint pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leptospirosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with high fever, severe headache, muscle pain, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, and a history of exposure to flooded rice paddies.


Explanation for other options:

Dengue (Option A) presents with fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash but lacks conjunctival suffusion and calf tenderness.

Malaria (Option B) is characterised by cyclical fever, splenomegaly, but does not cause conjunctival suffusion.

Filariasis (Option D) leads to lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis, without conjunctival suffusion or myalgia.

questions.text: A 13-year-old patient presents with perianal itching, mostly at night. A swab was taken, and the microscopic image showed oval eggs with a flattened side, as the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scotch-tape test:

A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.

Life cycle:

  • Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans.
  • It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration.
  • The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults.
  • The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the faeces.
  • The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all its eggs or gets crushed due to scratching.

Pathogenicity:

  • The embryonated egg is the infective form.
  • The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults.
  • It affects females > males.
  • The infection occurs in two ways:
    • Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by the nails after scratching the region.
    • Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin.
  • Larvae: The larvae mature in the cecum into adult worms and are not infectious forms of Enterobius.

Explanation for other options:

Hymenolepis nana (Option A) The dwarf tapeworm typically causes abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea, but not perianal itching.

Ancylostoma and Necator americanus (Options B and D) Ancylostoma, now known as Necator americanus, is a hookworm that primarily causes iron deficiency anaemia, ground itch, and creeping eruption.

questions.text: A soldier presents with fever, rash, and neck stiffness. Lab tests indicate a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC). Which organism is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neisseria meningitidis is the likely cause of bacterial meningitis. The symptoms of fever, rash, and neck rigidity, combined with the deficiency in the membrane-attacking complex, are consistent with this diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Neisseria gonorrhoea (Option B) primarily affects the genital tract and anorectal region and is not associated with meningitis.

Klebsiella (Option C) causes community-acquired pneumonia, catheter-associated UTI, and sepsis.

CMV (Option D) typically causes hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and purpuric rashes.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicular lesions in the genitourinary region. The image shows multiple grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the image and the clinical features, the causative agent is Herpes.

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus:

  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)
    • Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.
    • Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.
    • Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler's herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.
    • Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)
  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection)
    • Recurrent herpes labialis
  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers
    • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
    • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis)
    • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
    • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

Explanation for other options:

Chancroid (Option B) causes painful ulcers but typically presents as a single, larger ulcer with ragged edges, not multiple vesicles.

Syphilis (Option C) causes painless genital ulcers.

Candidiasis (Option D) does not cause painful vesicular lesions.

questions.text: Which disease is commonly referred to as "Desert Rheumatism"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Options B, C, and D are not referred to as Desert Rheumatism.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is associated with broad-based budding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blastomyces is associated with broad-based budding.

Explanation for other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option A) appears as rosettes of conidia on microscopy.

Talaromyces marneffei (Option C) appear as brush/broom conidia on microscopy.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (Option D) is characterized by a "pilot's wheel" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance of the yeast form.

Reference:

  1. PAS and GMS utility in dermatopathology: Review of the current medical literature - Shalin - 2020 - Journal of Cutaneous Pathology - Wiley Online Library
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441987/

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient with more than 104 colonies of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus in Urine Culture. What is the expected course of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) in significant numbers (>10^4 colonies) suggests a urinary tract infection.

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)

Etiology and Prevalence:

  • Primary Cause: Colonic bacteria ascending the urinary tract.
  • Common Pathogen: Escherichia coli (54-67% of cases).
  • Other Pathogens: Klebsiella spp., Proteus spp., Enterococcus, Pseudomonas,Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Clinical Features and Classification:

  • Pyelonephritis (Kidney Infection): Upper renal collecting system involved
    • Symptoms: Abdominal/back/flank pain, fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
    • Newborns: Non-specific symptoms like poor feeding, irritability, jaundice, weight loss.
  • Cystitis (Bladder Infection): Only bladder involved
    • Symptoms: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain, incontinence, malodorous urine.
    • Typically does not cause high fever or renal injury.

Risk Factors for Recurrent UTI:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)
  • Bladder-Bowel Dysfunction (BBD)
  • Obstructive Uropathy
  • Urinary Tract Abnormalities: Anatomical issues like labial adhesion.
  • Neuropathic Bladder
  • Catheterisation: Procedures introducing bacteria.
  • Sexual Activity: Increases UTI risk in females.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine Culture: Gold standard for UTI diagnosis; identifies and quantifies bacteria.
  • Interpretation:
  • A colony count of >50,000 colony-forming units/mL of a single pathogen, along with pyuria or bacteriuria in a symptomatic child, is generally considered diagnostic of a UTI.
  • Urinalysis: Leukocyte Esterase and Nitrites positive.
  • Imaging Studies:

Treatment:

  • Antibiotic Therapy: Mainstay of UTI treatment.

Explanation for other options:

Take three urine samples (Option B) Multiple urine samples are needed for bloodstream infections (bacteremia), not for UTIs.

No treatment is needed (Option C) A colony count ≥104 CFU/mL in a symptomatic patient requires treatment.

Contaminated sample (Option D) S. saprophyticus is a known UTI pathogen, not a contaminant like other CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis).

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation for other options:

CMV (Option A) causes periventricular calcifications, sensorineural hearing loss, and blueberry muffin rash.

Rubella (Option B) causes PDA, cataracts, and deafness (congenital rubella syndrome).

Zika (Option D) causes microcephaly, cortical thinning, and intracranial calcifications.

Reference:

  1. Congenital Cytomegalovirus Infection - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Congenital Toxoplasmosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a prior helminth infection presents with motile larvae (~200 microns) in the stool, while no eggs are detected. Which of the following parasites is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rhabditiform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis hatch and migrate to the intestinal lumen and are excreted in the stool. No eggs are seen.

Explanation for other options:

Ancylostoma (Hookworm) (Option A) eggs, not larvae, are found in stool. Causes iron deficiency anaemia due to intestinal blood loss.

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option B), large eggs with thick-walled, mammillated surfaces are seen in stool, not larvae.

Schistosoma (Option C) non-motile ova with characteristic spines (lateral in S. mansoni, terminal in S. haematobium) are found in stool or urine.

questions.text: An ICU patient develops a central line-associated infection. Microscopy reveals gram-positive, oval-shaped organisms reproducing by budding. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Candida species are yeast-like fungi that reproduce by budding and can cause central line infections, especially in immunocompromised patients.

Explanation for other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): These are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option C): These are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Escherichia coli (Option D): These are gram-negative rods.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with an infection caused by Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) O157:H7. In this serotype designation, what does the "H" denote?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "H" antigen in E. coli serotyping refers to the flagellar antigen, which determines the motility of the bacteria.

O157:H7 is a strain of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) known for producing Shiga toxin, leading to hemorrhagic colitis and Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS).

Serotyping of E. coli:

  • "O" antigen → Somatic (LPS) antigen (Option D)
  • "H" antigen → Flagellar antigen (Option C)
  • "K" antigen → Capsular antigen (Option A)

Fimbriae (Option B) aid in bacterial adhesion, but they are not part of E. coli serotyping as the "H" antigen.

questions.text: A male patient reports urethral discharge that is purulent, along with a recent history of unprotected sexual contact. Microscopic examination shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci as in the image. What is the recommended first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of purulent urethral discharge and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Microscopy revealing gram-negative intracellular cocci is suggestive of gonorrhea.

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with corneal ulcers and diminished vision. He was very careless about his lens fluid. On microscopy, an organism with spikes is identified. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of corneal ulcer, spikes seen on microscopy and history of improper contact lens use is suggestive of Acanthamoeba infection.

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites.
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes :
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a history of prolonged fever with discolouration of the skin over the lower limb and oedema. Microscopy reveals a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis.

The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail.

Brugia timori:

  • Periodicity: Nocturnal
  • Vector: Anopheles barbirostris

questions.text: A traveller develops diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and vomiting after consuming oysters. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a common cause of gastroenteritis linked to the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters. The typical symptoms include diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and vomiting, often appearing within 24 hours of ingestion. 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a gram-negative bacterium, part of the Vibrio genus, commonly found in marine environments. It causes gastroenteritis primarily through the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters. 

Transmission:

  • Ingestion of contaminated seafood, particularly raw oysters and fish, is the primary route of infection.
  • Associated with coastal areas and warm seawater.

Clinical Features:

  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Symptoms typically appear within 24 hours of consuming contaminated food.

Virulence Factors:

  • Haemolysin production (particularly thermostable direct haemolysin) is responsible for cell damage and intestinal symptoms.
  • Adhesion factors that help the bacteria adhere to the intestinal mucosa.

Diagnosis:

  • Stool culture is used for diagnosis. The bacterium can be isolated from the stool of infected individuals.

Treatment:

  • Supportive care (hydration and electrolyte replacement)
  • Doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or third-generation cephalosporins are used in severe cases or for immunocompromised patients.

References:

  1. Three New Regulators of Swarming in Vibrio parahaemolyticus - PMC.

questions.text: A farmer suffered a wound on the dorsum of his foot. It later involved the subcutaneous tissue and became a discharging ulcer. Microscopy reveals gram-positive branching filaments. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sporothrix (Option B) Patients with sporotrichosis will usually present with a history of thorn prick followed by ulcers/pustules formation at the trauma site and lymphadenopathy.

Histoplasma (Option C) is caused by bat or bird droppings and affects the reticuloendothelial system.

Candida (Option D) on microscopy, candida will appear as both buds and pseudohyphae forms.
